The Chiefs of Staff made the following reports in amplification-tion of the information contained in Cabinet War Room RecordsNos. 527-529.The heavy loss of our bombers on the night of the 11th Februaryhad been due to a heavy fog having developed over this countryseveral hours before it had been expected. Landing had been impossible and crews had been ordered to bale out. We had lost22 aircraft. Of the crews in these aircraft totalling over 100, allbut 5 were safe. The crews of three Coastal Command aircraft were, however, still missing.The Prime Minister said that he hoped that the Commander- )in-Chief, Bomber Command, realised that the War Cabinet did not /press for bombing operations to be undertaken when weather con-jditions were unfavourable. The Chief of the Air Staff said that:this was fully realised. . . german fighters had now been encountered over Malta.A homeward-bound convoy of 19 ships from Sierra Leone hadbeen shelled by an enemy raider on the morning of the 12th Februarywhen 640 miles west of Cape St. Vincent. Several ships had beenreported sunk or sinking, but no further details had been received.The Germans claimed to have sunk 13 ships in this convoy.Six Italian ships, totalling 30,000 tons, which had left Kismayuhad been captured.Red Sea Littoral. A column of an Indian Infantry Brigadewas advancing from Karora towards Nakfa.Central Eritrea. A column of Indian troops was short ofKeren. An Infantry Brigade was attacking from the South. Thesouthern column advancing from Barentu was held up near MaiMefales.Kenya. In the north our troops had reached some 50 miles north of Dukana. On the eastern frontier our troops had reachedAfmadu.The Prime Minister said that the possibility of raising a forceof Free Italians was being examined. Recruits might be obtainedfrom the prisoners captured.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.foreign information.Yugoslavia.Tripoli.Japan.(previous reference:W.M. The Permanent Under-Secretary of State for foreign fairs gave the following information : The Yugoslav President of the Council and Minister forForeign Affairs might visit Germany in the near future. Yugoslaviaseemed to be under German pressure.A report had been received that the Italian forces in Tripoliwere in process of being evacuated by sea to Italy.A report had been received (not yet confirmed from other sources) that all Japanese ships had received orders to return to japan by the 1st March.3. The Prime Minister said that he thought the best course totake with regard to the Asaka Maru was to allow her to load up at Lisbon and to detain her if necessary on her return journey.This would give more time for consideration of the action to betaken in regard to this vessel.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.[22227]b 2 Parliament. 4. The War Cabinet had before them a further revised draftM.P.'s and of the House of Commons Disqualification (Temporary Provisions)Offices under Bill (W.P. (G) (41) 23), prepared on the lines agreed at theirthe Crown. previous Meeting.Reference- ^e ^ar Cabinet decided as follows : W.M. (41) 1.6th (1) The Certificate in Clause 1 (i) of the Bill should be givenConclusions.) by the First Lord of the Treasury, and not by the lords commissioners of the Treasury;(2) Words should be inserted to make it clear that the measure,although renewable annually, would in no case continue in force after the present emergency.(3) Subject to these amendments, the Bill was approved, andshould be introduced into the House of Commons in thefollowing week;(4) The Chancellor of the Exchequer was invited to furnish the Prime Minister (who would speak on the SecondReading) as soon as possible with a full statement of allcases in which Members of both Houses of parliament had, since the beginning of the war, accepted offices or employment under the Crown. This statement should include cases covered by statutory exceptions; e.g.,M.P.'s serving in the Armed Forces or as regional commissioners. The Prime Minister would then decide whether a statement containing these particulars shouldbe laid before Parliament in the form of a White Paper.In the meantime, the Chancellor of the Exchequer woulddefer answering the unstarred Parliamentary question on this subject put down by Mr. R. Gibson, M.P.5. The War Cabinet had before them a Report by the lord president of the Council (W.P. (G) (41) 13) dealing with the recon-struction of town and country. Attached to the Report was an appendix which defined the organisation required to assist theMinister of Works and Buildings in carrying out the duties assigned to him in preparing for the physical reconstruction of town and country after the war, and indicated generally the scope of thepreliminary studies which should be undertaken through this organisation.The Minister of Labour and National Service asked that therepresentative of his Department should be a permanent memberof the Advisory Committee (proposed in paragraph 5 of theAppendix) to be appointed by the Minister of Works and Buildings.This was agreed to.The War Cabinet-Approved the proposals in the Report by the lord president of the Council and the Appendix thereto(W.P.
